Followups: bad positions and failed attacks are just another link in the chain. While we don’t want to train expecting that we’ll fail, it always makes sense to have a secondary plan of attack in case things go wrong. Practicing in this way does two things: it puts you in the mindset of preparation, where you always have a contingency plan, and it trains you in the habit of looking for good alternatives. You can be committed to an attack or a defense and still keep an eye on what’s coming next.
We begin here in an inferior position (partner in the rear standing body lock). Our first response is the rolling kneebar which puts us both in on the legs and down on the ground, where we prefer to work to control our partner. The follow up attack, cross ashi via the iminari roll, reconnects us to the legs after our partner has defended. Although we can plan in advance to execute a specific sequence, we need to be equally prepared to follow up in the moment given the variables of whatever situation we’re in.
@shoyoroll // @judoshintaronyc // video @gragin1
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #footsweep #kosoto #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Contingency plans: when your first efforts fail, it’s easy to lose focus. In the case of guard passing, your partner’s rentention work is there to deliberately interrupt your efforts. They will throw posts, frames, knee shields, leg pummeling at you to maintain distance and offset your balance. Having a plan in place for how to handle common distractions will help you work your way out of them instead of getting sidetracked. What adjustments will you need to make if something unexpected sets you back? What will you do if you can’t physically handle power or strength? Instead of simply reacting, which often pulls you further from your central aim, you’ll be in a better position to handle both your goal and the distraction at the same time.
@shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Hierarchy of failure: there are not many serious failures, so long as you follow a path of dedicated long-term effort based on learning and incremental improvement. There will be mistakes, of course - that kind of failure should be expected and even prevalent in your practice during certain times in your life. But compared to some other sorts of failures, your errors will barely register. Consider the failure of the person who never begins, or the one content to criticize without participating. Then there’s failure of those who start but quit when the honeymoon’s over and the real work begins. Think about the failure of the person who looks only for shortcuts, never willing to endure the slog of the long, hard road home. All of these seem much more difficult to endure than whatever mistakes we make in the name of persistent improvement. Long-term commitment is what yields results and growth. So get moving and start failing - just be sure to keep going. 
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #newwavejiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Grips: in an ideal world, we’d break all of the grips that interfered with our efforts to attack. But in reality, it’s impossible to strip every offensive grip we encounter. With a strong person it can be difficult for us to break even the simplest grips, like a standard sleeve or straight lapel. When we can’t strip a grip, we need to look for ways to turn that grip to our advantage. In the standing position, we can use our partner’s strong sleeve grip to draw them forward into our tai otoshi. After an initial pull to confirm their grip, we use it to bring them forward and then interrupt it with our blocking leg. Seeking out alternatives to breaking “impossible” grips can make you more proactive, less defensive, and more creative overall in your practice.
@eugenenyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll 
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #grip #taiotoshi #tachiwaza #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Old habits: in the process of building new habits, your old ones will inevitably resurface. This makes sense - by definition they’re deeply ingrained ways of thinking or looking at your training. When you notice yourself failing to address a grip or mistiming a takedown, locking your legs the wrong way or fumbling a guard pass, prime yourself to make the correction DELIBERATELY and CONSCIOUSLY. It’s obvious to want to fix an error. When you do it consistently and on purpose, every single time, you set the stage to see the problem earlier and to fix it sooner. Those times when you miss the chance, notice when you’ve missed it and you’ll still be increasing your awareness of what needs to change. The more often you do this the easier, more natural and more automatic it becomes. With practice you’ll learn to execute the new habit much earlier in the process.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #newwavejiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Students old and new: In Boston filming an upcoming video with trusty friends Placido Santo @placisantos and Brian Glick @bzglick Brian was one of my most talented students over many years in the blue basement in NYC. His jiu jitsu story is one of my favorites. He was so delicate and fragile looking when he first began training over twenty years ago that on two occasions I took him aside and told him I thought it would be wise for him to stop training and find an easier and safer recreation. I have never been so happy to have been proven wrong as he developed a truly deep and impressive game both gi and no gi. Like many of my early students he chose not to compete but always he was in the gym through the MMA era with Georges St Pierre and the grappling era with the early squad all the way through until we left for Puerto Rico. It’s been a blast reliving old memories and teaching alongside him today. Tomorrow the three of us are back it! I’m sure you’ve all got your crazy friends at Jiu jitsu class - I think part of the appeal of jiu jitsu is the lunacy of the people around us and the reflection it offers for our own lunacy to be doing such a crazy sport! 😂😜😂

Speed is relative: living in New York, you get used to a very specific pace of life. When the light turns green, you’ve got just a fraction of a second to start moving before the honking starts. Sometimes that speed confers an advantage; other times you find that it just gets you going to the wrong place faster. If you visit another city, you quickly realize that people don’t move at the same speed you’re used to. The same thing is true for your work on the mat. There’s not an ABSOLUTE speed that’s intrinsically better than another. There’s no outer limit and no minimum that’s essentially “correct”; your speed is only correct when it allows you to achieve your desired result. We can miss important details in the effort to move faster than someone else; other times we miss opportunities because we didn’t react quickly enough. There’s no “right speed”, but you can make use of speed if you align it with your objectives. Consider whether your SPEED matches your GOALS and your STRATEGY - not compared to what other people are doing but compared to what you’re trying to get done yourself.
📸 @peterpabon
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Growth: many of us would like to change something about our jiu-jitsu but find it very difficult. It’s a powerful skill to take a look at your practice and see that you need to make an adjustment. This experience may come from frustration - things may get so bad that you’re finally faced with the fact that you need to add something, a particular skill or defense to your arsenal. Other times you reflect on something that’s important to you - having a triangle that really works, or feeling more comfortable in the standing position - and resolving to get serious about it. 
Then there are still other times when the experience comes as inspiration, watching mastery in action or seeing another person’s process of change. I’ve been fortunate enough to be surrounded by some incredibly talented peers and training partners over the years (@gordonlovesjiujitsu is of course at the top of the list) so this has been a big part of my own growth. 
The skill of taking an honest look, recognizing that things aren’t working and that you need to make some changes to what you’re doing, can be difficult to learn. That's OK - like many other skills in jiu-jitsu it happens over time. Surrounding yourself with the best people will help, but the key is to begin the process. Don’t linger in indecision, planning and research - find the way that works for YOU to flip the switch and get started. @bjj.fanatics 
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Plans vs. shortcuts: real “shortcuts” in jiu-jitsu are few and far between. Instead of spending your time looking for shortcuts, a better strategy is to spend your time crafting a plan. A plan involves steps that are generally under your control. It includes the difficult, slogging work of trying, testing and failing, then having to consistently maintain whatever you find that works. We may enjoy the feeling (and the credit) of the shortcut when we find one. But having a plan beats hacking for a shortcut any day.
📸 @peterpabon 
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Exactitude: it can be difficult to find a solution that fits the problem you’re trying to solve 100%. But if you look around you’ll see there are solutions that are close enough to provide you with useful clues, even if they're not form-fitting, air-tight answers. So whenever you feel like your one particular problem is a perfectly impossible situation that's the result of unique causes, think again. Your problem isn't completely unique - it’s related to other ones you’ve seen before. Not only that, but your peers and teachers have been in your shoes before and have worked with a similar situation. Some have succeeded, others have failed...and you can learn from them all. Often your search for the exact prescription is procrastination in disguise. So once have a hint and you're pointed in the right direction, your job is to start moving forward - even if it’s without 100% certainty.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Goals: in jiu-jitsu, new goals present themselves all the time, not just at the new year. And as happens with all new goals, it’s easy to charge forward into the new year full-speed ahead looking at all the things you want to accomplish. But it makes sense to remind ourselves of where we are - both the positive and negative - to keep new goals from seeming like they’re too far off. Take a moment to consider what you’ve accomplished already over the past year, then consider how you’ll begin to approach whatever new plans you have ahead. What skills or goals have you put the most effort into? What are you happy about? What more would you like to have done? After you’ve reflected on these, move on to what you’re looking forward to. What advantages do you have that could make progress more likely? What might get in the way? How can you avoid them before they show up? Over the years I’ve found that these questions are both encouraging and strategic - they help to assess present strengths and weaknesses and frame out what’s next. Wherever you are, don’t underestimate your power to take things in a new direction. Happy new year 😊
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Making space - taking space: a general truth in jiujitsu is when we want to defend or escape, we look to make space in order to regain freedom of movement. When we’re on offense, we look to restrict our partner’s movement by tightening everything up. Similarly, when you move from one position to another you’ll find yourself needing to expand and contract to adapt to your partner’s reactions. Too tight and you won’t be able to move at all; too loose and you’ll lose your connection. The result is not unlike an accordion or a rubber band, which can expand and contract easily depending on what is required. If you can learn to work within this “accordion space” - managing distance and remaining flexible in how you do it - you’ll find you can move more fluidly and transition more easily. 
 @judoshintaronyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #ashigarami #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

The improvement triad: everyone wants to “get better”, but how do you know where you should focus your daily training? While you can (and should) rely on advice and suggestions from teachers, you also need to understand what YOU need in order to put their good advice into practice. The three areas to focus on are what’s important, what you don’t currently do very well, and what you’re capable of doing a lot better if you invested effort and time. Your priority is at the intersection of these three concerns. Eliminate what’s not important, what you can’t get better at (for whatever reason) and what you’re already good at. What’s left is where your best work will be done.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Comfort zones: jiu-jitsu gives us the strategic guidance and technical means to avoid becoming overwhelmed by stress and pressure. This is usually a good thing, especially in sparring, randori, self-defense or a fight. But many of our most meaningful learning experiences come from times when we ARE overwhelmed and are thus required to go up to (or beyond) our current limits. These moments  can be physical - where our stability is challenged and we're literally stretched to our maximum capacity - or they can be psychological, where we get to the edge of what we know or understand. If you only spend time with what you know or can do, you won't time you spend with what you don’t. On the mat this mean means fewer chances to discover something new and problem-solve in a different way. So whenever you find yourself in a situation characterized by uncertainty, see it for what it is - an opportunity to uncover news ways to adapt and adjust. Your inclination may be to find security and stability, but a great deal of progress happens in those places where you’re least comfortable.
📸 @peterpabon 
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Handfighting: not all grips are created equal. In the standing position the exchange of grips - making them and breaking them - can often happen more quickly than on the ground, so familiarity with the hierarchy of hand positions becomes very important. The underhook confers an advantage with its inside position; the Russian tie gives the benefit of 2-on-1 control; the whizzer offers a chance for downward pressure and control of the shoulder. In a gripping exchange you may pass through many of these and more - wrist ties, collar ties, battling for head position. And all that’s before you even get into grabbing  the legs :) It’s good to remember that improving your understanding of these grips in the standing position will benefit your ground game as well - as above, so below.
@judoshintaronyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #ashigarami #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Invisible habits: it’s hard enough to change the habits you can see. The ones you CAN’T easily see are much more difficult. These are patterns or responses you don’t know you’re engaging in, and often they require another person (training partner, your instructor) to point them out. Retraining old habits is hard because they are deeply ingrained - you’ve been doing them for a long time, sometimes for years. You won’t be able to just “decide” you’d like to change them and see results in a day or two. In some cases it can take weeks, even months. But it helps to know that the process is often uneven and messy, with false starts and wrong turns along the way. What feels like a failure during this time isn’t really a failure IF YOUR AWARENESS OF THE PROBLEM INCREASES. Awareness is the essential first step. If you don’t know you’re doing something, you cannot retrain it and it will keep happening without you being able to do anything about it. Begin by seeing this habit in place and watch how it affects you. After that, developing an alternative is much easier.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Memorization vs. learning: both can be important, but only one requires understanding. Memorizing a set of techniques or mechanics can be done, of course, and you can even pass information along like this. If I remember all the steps to follow for a heel hook, I can recite all the steps to you also. In order to learn something, however, you have to go beyond just memorizing it - you have to UNDERSTAND it. In the process you might become so fluid and confident with your topic that it can LOOK like memorization - but that’s just a result of being immersed in the subject. We wouldn’t say that Ono has “memorized” uchimata or that Gordon has “memorized” the rear strangle. To become great at jiu-jitsu, judo or any other martial art is to build upon what you know, to improve it. Memorization can’t help with that. You need to take things a step further and really understand them.
📸 @peterpabon
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

The head and the legs: the front headlock offers excellent control from the standing position, so much so that even beginners who learn to wrap the head can quickly gain an advantage even with more experienced partners. One of the simplest skills to learn is that of bringing the head to the feet - with good contact, heavy pressure and just a little bit of movement we can affect posture and balance at the same time, and often this is enough to stumble even someone who is flexible and athletic. There are dozens of excellent variations on ankle picks from the front headlock and the collar tie. When you link them to submissions - guillotines at the upper body or leg locks down below - you have a fluid means of controlling someone throughout the transition from standing down to the ground.
🎥 @athleteplus // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma #shoyoroll

(No) control: although we’re always looking for ways to gain better control through jiu-jitsu, there will always be factors OUTSIDE of our control. Some of these are attributes - we can’t do much about how tall we are, how long our arms might be or our age. Others have to do with physics - we can’t affect the laws of gravity, for instance. But there are plenty of things we can do to control how we INTERACT with these limits of control. You can learn to mitigate the power of gravity by improving your balance, or even better learn to use gravity to your advantage through kuzushi. With shorter legs you might not be able to do a triangle quite as easily but you can dedicate yourself to an upper body attack, like the kimura or guillotine, where the length of your legs is not as important. If you’re older you could avoid tricky inversions and focus instead on your half-guard. Above all, you could choose not to grumble about your shortcomings and all the things you can’t do. Just because we encounter forces that are out of our control doesn’t mean we can’t do anything about how they influence our practice and our lives.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Evasive tactics: these three late-stage responses - evasive maneuvers - are all about rotating out of big throws: ushiro tomoe nage, yoko tomoe nage and osoto gari. Where most jiu-jitsu answers to these throws are conservative, these represent a class of riskier, more athletic defensive responses. Over the years I always watched in wonder when @judoshintaronyc , @gstleger or @harrystleger would use these sorts of tactics as counters in live randori. While most of them never became my “go-to”responses in a live situation - and probably won’t be yours either – they represent the sort of creative, dynamic, audacious problem-solving that always has a place in good training. 
@eugenenyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #judothrow #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Filtering: the world of jiu-jitsu is a world without filters, so you have to bring your own. When you lack structure or a plan, you’ll also lack the space and focus you need to apply your experiences to your work. If your objective is to improve or refine your back attacks, success starts when you begin to apply a filter. Start with a goal and a plan to get there: how can you work your way to the back against some resistance so you can then implement techniques or tactics you’ve learned? Or you can filter a step further by narrowing your efforts through positional or situational training - set training conditions so you can start on the back to work from there. Filters like these narrow your focus and keep you from the edge of information overload. Become purposeful about consistently looking to add capacity-increasing filters into your training and you’ll be setting yourself up for high-level breakthroughs.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

More friends 😊. Amazing to have one of my old mentors and friends in town for a few days to experiment with some new stuff we have each been working on. Always a pleasure to have @bzglick here.

Connections: we often focus on the importance of forming strong connections in training - knee-to-elbow in order to create a strong frame, or chest-to-back to keep pressure and advance our attacks. No less essential are the connections we form with the people we train with. For as much as jiu-jitsu can be an arena of individual achievement (or a space where we face off “against” each other), it can never come to life without the mutual participation of our peers and partners. What we do thrives on interactions - connections of all sorts which bring out the best in us. I’ve been incredibly privileged over the years to have such a talented cohort of partners and friends to help guide my practice and progress. I’ve learned so much from their feedback, example and insights. It’s been great to reconnect with them this week!!
@gordonlovesjiujitsu @giancarlobodoni @chrisweidman @nicholasmeregali

The gift of gi: training in Austin last week with the absolute champ, the incredible @nicholasmeregali. Although jiu-jitsu practitioners overall are becoming more and more specialized, choosing to focus on either gi or no gi, he has dedicated himself to excellence in both. In my own training I was always taught to view gi and no gi as two halves of the same whole - instead of exerting ourselves twice as hard to keep up with two complex, discreet types of environments, we can study both and get to know them from the inside. Over time we begin to recognize the concepts and movements they share so they can inform and benefit one another. Very grateful!

#repost @nicholasmeregali 
・・・
I had a great time training with my friend and legend @bzglick Yesterday was the third time I dressed my Gi up for having some sparring since I got my Absolute World Title IBJJF. The kimono is my true love

Investment: every day we invest part of ourselves into our training. One of the most important choices available to us is WHERE we make that investment. That technique you’re practicing, that strategy you’re implementing - are they worth your investment? Committing to the wrong thing for a week or two isn’t the end of the world. But spending months (or years!) focusing on something that isn’t working or is leading you in the wrong direction might be. So don’t just “set it and forget it” - if you’re dug deeply into a particular way of doing things, make sure to look up every once in a while to make sure it’s taking you where you want to go.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Relevance: when we go to work on particularly sticky problems, we try to limit ourselves to information related to those problems. Such limits allow us to focus more effectively on the issue we’re trying to solve. A “deep dive” lets you immerse yourself in the particulars of this trouble area so you can make real progress on it. If you constantly see people defending your single leg, don’t just move on to something else. Consider it a prompt to look more closely at your grips and movement in general, and your strategy in particular. This can lead you from a problem (like strong single leg defense) into a solution (like ashiwaza). A good rule of thumb is to include your own experience (what you’ve learned and the problems you have solved yourself) and the experience of other people (teachers near and far, and your peers). Even if you’re a generalist by nature, you can become a specialist during times when you face a lot of resistance or difficulty. This helps to avoid losing focus and moving onto “easier problems” as well as the distractions that can come with too much non-essential info.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Reaction vs. response: factors like speed, power, connection and pressure allow you to set your agenda in training. The trouble is that they also allow your partner to set THEIR agenda. When we find ourselves behind, we can either REACT to what is going on or we can RESPOND to what’s going on. Our reactions are shortcuts, learned habits out of our control that may not suit the situation we face. Responses are different: they’re actions that work on purpose to produce the outcome we seek. When we think through our choices and select the best option, we have an opportunity to proactively shift how things are going for us. It’s rarely the easy choice - it takes more focus and preparation, less excuse-making and blaming - but it’s the one experts make (and often part of what makes them experts).
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Outside position: in the battle for grips and  position, a posted inside arm can be a formidable barrier. It provides a means of creating and maintaining distance, and it gives you the power to either keep someone at bay or to close the gap between you. When we’re on the receiving end of a strong posted arm (as in standing), one great option is to move from INSIDE TO OUTSIDE position. There are number of ways to do this - the arm drag, the Russian 2-on-1 and the over-tie are some examples you’ll recognize. They all offer excellent opportunities to form a strong connection to our partner by working OUTSIDE the arm. Here we use a chopping motion at the elbow to fold a strong stiff arm; we keep it bent with a far lat grip and chest-to-arm connection. Although our partner does have their arm on the inside, the strength of our connection makes it difficult for them to use it. We, on the other hand, can launch a series of attacks (kouchi, ouchi and sumi)even without our preferred positioning. As with many things in training, we have to make the best of the options we have available. Learn to play both inside and outside position and you’ll be more versatile, ready to attack from anywhere.
@eugenenyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #judothrow #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma
5 no gi judo attacks from the throw by with @bzglick producer cred: @gragin1

Effort: When we detach our emotional state from the OUTCOME of our effort, we’re more likely to remain focused and effective. We’re not trying to CONTROL the outcome in an absolute sense; we’re just putting our best effort into creating the CONDITIONS for that outcome. A good way to make this work in your training is first to choose an area of focus - something simple enough so you can return to it even with distractions and resistance - then direct your effort there. It could be a particular leglock or guillotine entry, if that’s what you’ve been working on; it could also be a particular passing sequence, or the firm goal of getting to your partner’s back. Once you set your focus in this way, you’ll have a chance to dedicate your best resources to a worthwhile goal. Then just be prepared to accept what happens once you’ve done your utmost. Choose a goal, dedicate yourself to your plan, execute it to the best of your ability - and be ready to accept whatever happens after.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

#repost @danaherjohn

Filming in Boston! It’s been great as always working with two of my favorite students Brian Glick @bzglick and Placido Santos @placisantos on a new video in the gi! It’s crazy cold here in Boston with a big snowfall today - it’s been a long time since I walked in heavy snow! Now it’s time for dinner and then back to work tomorrow!

Fixes: jiu-jitsu can be complicated, even overwhelming at times. Even after years of practice, you will still find things that don’t work as well as you’d like. But getting deep into the work of problem-solving is one of the great experiences of training - not only do you learn to seek out and discover new solutions, you become better at detecting when it’s time to make changes or adjustments. The first step is to see when something is not working. If you tell yourself it’s not broken - or if you don’t know it’s broken - you won’t fix it. If you know there’s a problem and you fix it but learn nothing in the process, you’ll find it broken again soon. And if you know something is not working but don’t care enough to find a solution or learn how to make it better, nothing will happen. Changes happen when we see something that doesn’t work, we know it doesn’t work, we go to work to fix it right away (often with help from others) and learn from the process. This is a transferable skill, essential for any creative practice. Care enough to fix what’s wrong and over time you’ll see big changes.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Student-teacher: a great gift to be back with my teacher once again. The student-teacher relationship is like none other - for me it is a source of guidance, inspiration, direction and power. And it’s one I’m happy to say I can continue to benefit from, even over 20 years into it.

#repost @danaherjohn
・・・
Pajama party: Filming my latest video in Boston with the inestimable Brian Glick @bzglick my long suffering student from NYC days and a true jiu jitsu treasure. We are filming video on Jiu jitsu for older and less athletic players - I feel like this is one thing I am truly qualified to teach because I’m an old cripple! 😂😂 Nothing makes me happier as a coach than seeing an older or less athletic student taking on a much younger or athletically gifted opponent in the dojo and giving him hell - that’s when you really see the magic of jiu jitsu!

Categorizing: there’s a temptation to boil your performance or experience down to just one word - good, bad, hard, easy, fine, frustrating, successful. But there’s no pressure to categorize your experiences, efforts or process into just a single word or feeling. What you really encounter is always a combination of experiences - parts will have gone according to expectations, others will have surprised you; some were extraordinary, others average. The more relevant question is, “which part are you focusing on?” If you’re focusing on what was “good”, you might be overlooking parts that were disappointing or need work. If you’re focusing only on what went wrong, you could be missing one or two things that actually worked. Our narration determines our experiences and what we remember. If it’s not working, you can adjust it to suit your needs at the moment. 
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Ude-gaeshi +: our limbs are stronger together than they are apart, a fact we can see both on the ground and in the standing position. This grip begins as a classic Russian 2-on-1 tie and ends up as a closed lock on our partner’s bent arm. Because it is such a powerful grip, it can be used to direct the upper body (through pushing and pulling) as well as the lower body (through ashiwaza attacks). Here we use this figure-4 to pressure forward and create a set of reactions from our partner: ude gaeshi when there’s a gap between us; kosoto or ouchi when he presents the near leg; kouchi and knee pick when he presents the far leg; then an armdrag and deep kouchi when he posts the far arm to defend. You can start with a single grip or set up (like this one), then practice transitioning between disparate techniques by intelligently addressing your partner’s responses - what they give you - instead of just insisting against their resistance. In time you’ll have a repertoire of techniques from a single starting place which you can access even when under duress.
@judoshintaronyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #judothrow #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Black belt: last Friday I was honored to teach a small newaza session at @kokushibudoinstitute , one of the bedrocks of judo in New York city since the 1960s. I was also very happy to graduate my friend and training partner @judoshintaronyc to black belt. As many of you know, Shintaro has had a long and decorated career in judo - a 2x world team member and 2x national judo champion - and has taught and coached many, many students over the years. Often letting go of things that we are already good at in order to develop new skills can be even harder than starting from scratch. To undertake such an effort requires humility, patience, enthusiasm and a love of learning, all of which he has an abundance. Above all he is an outstanding teacher and mentor, and an inspiring example of a truly lifelong martial artist. At a time when many people spend their lives looking for equilibrium and certainty, it's good to remember that others are busy stepping outside their comfort zone, expanding their perspective, painstakingly adding new skills and willingly accepting new challenges. I'm very grateful for the privilege of teaching, training with and learning from such a person. Congratulations sensei!
📸 @peterpabon
===
#judo #blackbelt #bjj #jiujitsu #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma #shoyoroll

First contact: establishing a point of first contact with your partner starts the ball rolling. When you face a swirl of pommelling legs and the snapping grips of an aggressive partner, it can be intimidating. This is one of the places where a clear first step becomes important. We often favor advancing on a partner “behind the hands”, much the way that a boxer will stay behind the jab, using it to gauge distance and create angle. The purpose of these initial grips isn’t always control; in fact it can be hard to gain much control over someone’s powerful legs with your arms. Instead it’s the chain’s first link, a connection that allows you to feel where their movement is and what its quality is like - frantic, effortful, smooth, erratic. After you’ve made this first contact you have your first data point. From there you can begin to unfurl your strategy accordingly. As in other endeavors you face, crossing the threshold into the unknown can be the most difficult step. But many of the imaginary concerns you have evaporate once you’re actually engaged, because you’re occupied with action rather than anxiety.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

A wonderful time with old (and new) friends in Connecticut: one of the core topics at our seminar last weekend had to do with training protocols and ways to improve the rate of progress you see in the classroom. There is nothing wrong with hard training - in fact there are many important lessons which can only be learned under the pressure that comes from strong resistance. But when it comes to new skill acquisition and developing technical precision, we need to have training protocols that will allow us to access the details we’re trying to reinforce. Too much intensity can actually make this process harder, so cultivating a set of conditions where you can work smoothly and technically is critical. Whether you are doing gi or no gi, leglocks or triangles or back attacks, develop the sort of trust and rapport with your training partners that will get you where you’re going faster. Thank you again to everyone who came out to this session – I had a great time and hopefully you learned something that will benefit your practice, both immediately and long-term! @shoreline_bjj 
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma #shoyoroll

Crossgrip and sleeve: for jiu-jitsu practitioners this particular grip is a vital source of attacks on the ground - and it’s equally effective from the standing position. Because you’re positioned on the outside of your partner’s arm, it’s much harder for them to establish a dominant collar grip on the inside. Your cuff control on the dominant arm also does a number on their offensive options. Being outside the arm also makes finding an advantageous attack angle much easier. Here we use it to attack in 5 ways: reverse katagaruma, drop seoi nage, collar drag, tai otoshi and finally sode tsurikomi goshi. For BJJ people the collar drag will be most effective and familiar - but developing facility with the others will amplify your attacks and improve your understanding of this important grip.
@eugenenyc // 📹 @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #judothrow #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

The art of problem-solving: problem solving in jiu-jitsu is as much about what will happen if you DON’T solve the problem as it is about actually solving it. Your technique won’t work in every situation; there will be times when you face someone who has the correct defense or a sharp counter to your attack. So once you can understand that your effort might fail, it’s up to you to start thinking about what your failure will look like - where you might end up, what are the consequences, how you’ll find a way to recover. In spite of how it might seem, the practice of considering failure isn’t pessimistic or bleak. It’s a key to solving problems - and it’s often the most proactive, solution-oriented thinking you can bring to your training.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Teaching: several great days of filming in Boston complete with the help of friends at @bjj.fanatics. Whenever I have the chance to teach - either for my own students, at a seminar or in this case for an instructional - I try to remember that the main person who really needs to learn the topic is ME 😛. Rather than a liability, I consider this a great asset and one of the great benefits of teaching. If you’re an instructor you have the opportunity to revisit a given topic in great depth - to ask new questions, reconsider what you know, re-examine what you’ve learned, and renew your interest in learning overall. And the more deeply involved you become in teaching, the more you realize how much your understanding is due to the relationships you’ve established with teachers, peers, training partners and friends. We enjoy the privilege of standing on the shoulders of giants.
Thank you to @placisantos, @michaelzenga and @bernardofariabjj for all your support and hospitality 😊 
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #bjjfanatics #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Specific training: whenever you feel that you’re struggling in a particular area, there’s no better remedy than targeting that problem in your practice. Strategizing and thinking through solutions can give you direction - but there’s no substitute for narrowing the focus of your physical training on the mat. When you dive deeply into a particularly thorny problem, things may seem to get worse before they get better…but dont despair. It’s probably because you’re finally looking clearly and directly at the thing you need to improve. If you can stick with it and do it consistently, you’ll find you come up with insights, patterns, problems and solutions you can work with immediately. You may suffer in the short term…but you’ll grow in the long term.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Follow through: practicing upper body throws is a good reminder of the importance of connection (chest to chest or hip to hip) and kuzushi (breaking balance). It also teaches another very important lesson – the importance of following through. If you practice as if that the last degree of rotation or lift doesn’t matter, you start to slow down even earlier and earlier until it DOES matter. You keep sliding backwards, easing off at the end because the job is basically done and pretty soon the technique stops working. Then you run into a tough person or situation where you actually NEED that last degree, and suddenly your whole effort falls apart (along with your confidence). Following through doesn’t only solve a technical problem. It fixes a bigger problem - the tendency to stop partway through the process.
@judoshintaronyc // 📹 @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #judothrow #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Overthinking: many people look for more options - but having TOO MANY options reduces your effectiveness (and situational intelligence). There are suddenly so many possible avenues that choosing one can seem impossible. Even when you create a decision tree - “if I do this, then that will happen, which means I need to decide this, and then that might happen, etc.” - you find yourself tumbling down a rabbit hole, never to emerge again. You research all the variations, which leads to more research, more to think about. Then you uncover more variations…which lead to more research. You can never analyze all the options, because there’s always some feature or element you can’t predict - all the unknown variables make things uncertain. You won’t know all the factors, all the probabilities. For this reason, we need to make decisions based on what we know and the most likely outcomes. Set limits - look deeply and work on the problem for specific period of time. Then decide how you’re going to tackle it and get to work.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Harder than you thought: changes - in the form of new technical additions to your arsenal, or more farther-reaching adjustments to perspective or strategy - are often more difficult than they first appear. This usually equates to a struggle; we work to refine and adjust one thing at a time until we end up with something we can use. The problem is that our fantasies about how change happens are just that - fantasies. We’re surprised that hand fighting to a collar grip is so tough. We think we’ll be ready to roll out a new D’arce defense after a few times practicing it. We are not masters of the guillotine in 3 days. And so on. It can be discouraging. But if you struggle without quitting, you will make it into the next phase of development. That space is where you can refine and polish these new changes and turn them into something really meaningful for your practice longterm.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#judo #bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

FAILED tomoe nage & FAKE tomoe nage: these techniques fall into a class of throws called sutemi waza, or sacrifice throws. Sacrifice throws are often thought of like a period the end of a sentence - in judo they often come at the end of a series of attacks because they’re considered difficult to chain to other techniques once you’ve committed to them. But they DO link very well to other throws in the same family (other tomoe nages), and they can put you in a great position on the ground (for jiu-jitsu practitioners this is often the most important part :)) Landing a clear tomoe nage or yoko tomoe is the goal…but remember that these double attacks work as a great alternative to simply pulling guard and link very well to open guard work even if they fail!
@judoshintaronyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #shoyoroll #judothrow #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Gradualism: many people build their practice around the notion of massive breakthroughs, technical advances or big leaps that will change everything. Others focus on closing the big gap, discovering the one missing piece that will shut down their entries and attacks and defenses. But success in offense or defense doesn’t usually happen this way. Instead we succeed – and fail – one step at a time. You never really add a bunch of techniques or skills all at once. They develop one at a time, or in chains of movement you build gradually. And you’re also swept one sweep at a time, submitted one attack at a time, thrown one throw at a time. That’s how progress looks - and it’s slow enough to study, to review and consider. This approach is kind of anticlimactic. Moving serially and systematically doesn’t have the flash or explosion of a sudden insight. But one at a time is sustainable. It’s replicable and reliable and long-term, and it’s how we really progress in jiu-jitsu.
📸 @slouching_toward_nirvana // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

It's such a privilege to be back again to work with my teacher (and to spend time with the great @bernardofariabjj!). As students we can all benefit from the guidance and influence of our instructors, no matter how long we've been around them. Throughout the years, mine has emphasized over and over the importance of consistently working on the 3 or 4 most meaningful elements at any given time - those techniques and tactics that lead to the best outcomes for you - and it’s never led me astray. By spending more of your time on fewer but higher-impact areas, you combat the problem of feeling scattered and disconnected...and your practice becomes both more efficient and more effective. Always gift to be alongside him!

We talked today about age and jiu jitsu, the relationship between training and technique development in the gi versus no gi and filmed the AGELESS JIU JITSU video that sparked the conversation. Two skills: to successfully evolve as a practitioner, there are two core skills you need to develop. The first is getting accurate information from the world. Right now there are more sources than ever. A part of your work as a student is to focus on filtering the data you’re receiving, and then to test it yourself. Through this process you can also see what might be missing, leaving you with new questions to ask as you make your way through the details. The second skill is being able to sort information, then to rank it based on importance. Many times we see something as urgent when it isn’t. Other times we ignore something that we need to address right away. Sometimes we mistake what works in a FEW situations for something that ALWAYS works. If you want to deal successfully with a changing set of goals - not to mention resistance and counters to your attacks and defenses - you’ve got to look deeply into them. If you  start with accurate information, then rank it based on how important it is, you’ll be able to ignore what ISN'T important and pay attention to what IS important.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Great to be back at my alma mater Columbia University to work with the Columbia University BJJ Club! We had a room full of focused students across all levels, most of whom probably should have been home studying for end-of-semester exams :) We covered a whole range of techniques - from standing to ground and from guillotines to go-behinds - but the biggest lesson was while it matters a lot that you have a general idea of where you're headed, it matters even more that you don't skip the preliminary steps in your hurry to get to there. The little steps might seem little, but if you miss even one you might not get the chance to execute on those that come later on. As an instructor it was awesome to watch everyone working step-by-step and bringing their full attention to their work. Thank you again to everyone who attended - hope to be back soon!
@columbiauniversitybjj @columbia

Cross-grip tai otoshi: sometimes an INDIRECT method is best when it comes to getting what you really want. The grip for this this tai-otoshi comes through misdirection - we fake a grip to the leg or belt (groin tap works fine too 😬) in order to secure the grip and throw. Any time you feint and prompt a reaction from your partner that draws their hands, legs or even their attention away from what you’re really after, you’ll find that you run into less resistance. Whether you do this by going from one collar to the other, from the lower body to the upper body, from a sleeve grip to a collar grip or from a high attack to a low one, misdirection can create a clear pathway for the grips you need for success.
@judoshintaronyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #judo #judothrow #taiotoshi #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma #shoyoroll

Rewards and punishments: in most cases it’s not the big mistakes that get you - it’s the little ones. In fact, your biggest errors are so glaring that you usually HAVE to do something about them. On the other hand many little mistakes aren’t even visible until it’s too late. Every time you muscle your way out of a submission, you get a small reward - the satisfaction of escaping a bad position, quickly and without hassle. You also get a punishment, coming sometime in the future, when you face a bigger, stronger or more technical person and that habit stops working for you. One way to change that future outcome is to fix your behavior now, before it gets to be too ingrained. Try this: just take a look at how often you’re cutting these little corners in a training session, when you let power or flexibility or speed fill in the technical gaps. Seeing them all lined up in a row might be enough to prompt a change of mind and habits.
📸 @jeffreyschu // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #leglocks #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

social_posts.post_text:
Thank you to my friends at @workshop.nyc for inviting me to come teach the final session of their seminar series. Professors Jin Yung and Aaron Milam have been valued training partners of mine for nearly 20 years; having a chance to see the great program and environment that they’ve built was a real treat. As I mentioned to the students in the training, learning jiu-jitsu can be complicated - a flood of details and demands on body and mind. That’s why it’s so important to slow things down enough so you can see, feel, and understand what’s happening. Training that awareness (along with technique) helps you become better at discovering when it’s time to reshape or alter your approach for better results. Thank you again to everyone who came to the session - hopefully it was helpful for you!
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Katagaruma-sumi gaeshi: from a quick two-handed grip break, you can use the outside sleeve grip to turn and drop underneath for a katagaruma variation. When it fails, because you’re on the outside, it’s a little easier for you to recover back up to your feet if needed. Once you’re there, remaining on the outside gives you access to one of our favorite throws - sumi gaeshi. What unites these two throws is the strong OUTSIDE position you have with your sleeve grip. Normally we advocate INSIDE position, especially when it comes to working from places like the clamp and leg entanglements. But when you’re standing, remaining on the outside of your partners arms is a huge asset: it’s more difficult for them to grip you and to get an advantageous angle to throw from. Keep the idea of outside position in mind and see where it leads you.
@judoshintaronyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#judo #jiujitsu #bjj #judothrow #katagaruma #sumigaeshi #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma #shoyoroll

Certainty: most times it makes sense to approach jiu-jitsu training with a sense of certainty. Having a plan is better than trying to improvise in the moment, when the pressures and stresses of real-time resistance might cause you to panic, become distracted or miss opportunities. But uncertainty can also become an asset if you learn to work with it. This sort of uncertainty shouldn’t be confused with sloppiness or panic. It’s more like a variable in the equation, an unknown that you’re prepared to deal with because you know you can’t account for every alternative. That way, instead of over-determining how you’ll solve a problem, you work with staying open enough to use your tools live and in the moment. It’s thinking faster so you can act faster and make the adjustments you need in order to stay ahead of the action. Working with uncertainty is to build a loose, relaxed focus that lets you remain comfortable anywhere - even while you’re trying to get somewhere specific.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

When sumi fails: once you become skilled at a particular a technique, people will begin to anticipate your setups and attacks. This is why it’s so important for you to be prepared to follow up with a secondary attack based on their response. In the case of sumi gaeshi, there are a few different counters, but you’ll often find people drifting to the opposite side of your sweep to avoid being taken over. In the process their arm becomes light enough to pass it across your body. From there you can follow up with another of our favorite sumi variations, this time with an overwrap/uppercut grip and an underhook. All that’s left is to put your back flat on the floor, tilt your partner and take them over.
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #sumigaeshi #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #shoyoroll

Under Pressure (“The Clamp Guard”) is here: about a month ago I took a trip up to Boston to film an instructional that I hoped would help smaller, weaker, less-skilled people improve their guard. These are the same techniques I've found to be successful over the years against people much tougher and stronger than me. And they're the some of the first ones I learned from my teacher @danaherjohn. Here's the core idea: it can be tough to be under pressure from a stronger, more athletic person. To spend all your time in guard retention and recovery is exhausting. What we need is a way not just to SURVIVE pressure, but to THRIVE under it. 

This instructional is designed to be used by anyone who knows the feeling of being flattened, smashed or crushed under a strong, tight passer. If you can confront the mechanics or the problems that are slowing you down from this position, you can use the "maximizing" philosophy to escape immediately into attacks. Once you know what to do, it's much easier to solve those problems earlier - and to spend less time under someone else's pressure and more time CREATING pressure of your own. 

When you play guard, you're making a commitment. You're combining the distance management skills with the ability to form meaningful connections that will lead you to sweeps and submissions. If you can do these every step, the seemingly slippery decisions you have to make become a lot more solid. 

Jiu-jitsu under pressure is tough, but it's where many of us spend most of our time, at least at the beginning of our practice. It's taken a while to get this out so thank you to everyone who's been asking me about it and patient enough to wait. Thank you @bjjfanatics, @michaelzenga and @bernardofariabjj for making it happen. I hope you'll give it a try. Link in bio 😊

Tough decisions: jiu-jitsu is full of tradeoffs. We‘re often faced with having to lose something in one area in return for gaining something in another. It’s the choice between the hanging on to the submission or guard pass that’s almost-but-not-exactly there, and moving on to the next opportunity. Changing tactics midstream is a skill…which means you can train it. The skill starts with recognizing what’s no longer working and then letting that go. And it can be an outdated mindset just as much as it can be an outdated technique or strategy. Developing the discipline to make these adjustments can alter your direction immediately. What we learn from jiu-jitsu training is that we can't change destinations immediately. But we can change DIRECTION immediately, and direction is very important.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Fireman’s carry and Georgian grip variations: 
most of the unorthodox attacks you encounter on the mat have their roots in conventional techniques - you just need to look more deeply to see them. This is why when we take time early on in our practice to learn the standard entries, grips and set-ups, it often pays massive dividends much later on in training. Learning the foundational components of advanced techniques gives you a deeper insight into the mechanics and the concepts behind them. The sorts of variations on katagaruma, sumi gaeshi and yoko wakare here (some of them just used at the Judo world championship in Doha) don’t come out of left field. If you study, train and practice them, you’ll find that they follow the same general rules of movement, off-balancing and commitment that you learn early in your practice. They’re just a *little* more involved 😃
@judoshintaronyc // video @gragin1 // @shoyoroll
===
#judo #bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #judothrow #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

What goes wrong: in jiu-jitsu it’s often the case that small mistakes lead to much larger ones. By over-reacting to one pass attempt, we become extended and open to another. By breaking a grip too forcefully we may succeed in stripping the grip but become vulnerable to a followup attack. Each error stresses us, then undermines our next response, which makes us more stressed and more likely to respond poorly. Most things that go wrong do so SLOWLY - we end up a situation of unintended consequences which take us into a downward spiral. The answer isn’t always to live with the cycle that caused the problem. It’s to become aware of WHEN the downward spiral starts. Once you find it, you can begin to understand what causes it - then learn to use that trigger to initiate a different cycle. This is much more difficult to do. But identifying the DOWN spiral and replacing it with something BETTER is the best longterm strategy for overcoming a bad cycle.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma

Clamp and flexibility: when you start working with the clamp guard, you may feel like your flexibility is an important factor. But as with many types of guard, there are a few postural corrections you can make to improve your effectiveness right away. Here’s one detail that will help you immediately: rather than remaining flat on your back with both shoulders on the floor, make sure that you’re ON YOUR SIDE. This small adjustment does several things. When both your shoulders are glued to the mat, you often experience a feeling of being pinned underneath a stronger, bigger person’s weight. Turning to your side allows you to reduce the amount of friction between you and the floor, making you more mobile. Once you get onto your side, you’ll find that you can move more freely. This also creates a better angle relative to your partner as you prepare to attack, letting you establish the inside position more easily and to manage their grips more effectively. Finally, it brings your legs closer to their upper body which gives you the illusion of flexibility (even if you have almost none). Link to the full clamp instructional from @bjjfanatics is in my bio. 
// @placisantos 🥋@shoyoroll

Constraints: every effort worth your time comes with constraints. On the mat, you're usually constrained by someone else’s resistance to what you’re trying to do. You want to clear the knee line to pass the guard, and they want to preserve the knee line to prevent you from passing. You want your hands locked, they want your hands unlocked. Whether you are vying for grips or head position or control of a limb, in most cases your goals are in direct opposition to those of the person you face. 
For most people the natural preference is to fight these constraints. You learn to strip away grips, reassert control of a joint and pressure forward. This works - when you battle constraints and eradicate them, not only do you advance your position and control, but you can gain access to new perspectives, new approaches and new solutions in the process. 
An alternative approach is to embrace the constraints you face. Use them as assets instead of liabilities and learn to work within them. Otherwise you may miss the chance to unlock their true value as potential avenues for new discovery. Out of this method comes creativity, innovation and insight. And if you can get used to thriving under constraints, it’s even easier to do well once they’re not there.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Agility, speed and misdirection: so happy to be back again in the hallowed halls of Penn State to work with the legendary @romanbravoyoung. Wrong in the short term: there are times you'll find yourself in a situation to which there seems to be no satisfactory solution. Maybe you've run out of ideas, or maybe you're in completely unfamiliar terrain, or maybe you’re just unable to get your bearings. The question I always ask myself in these sorts of situation is: “what can I do to correct this difficulty or at least reduce the likelihood that I’ll face the same one in the future?“ This is what mistakes in training are about - the serious practitioner is usually happy to be WRONG IN THE SHORT TERM if it means that they will be RIGHT IN THE LONG TERM. You may not solve the problem on the first go round. But asking questions whenever you face an issue you can’t figure out can help you to turn a perpetual problem into just a temporary condition.
 📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Simple solution to a frustrating problem: controlling movement from the top of the high mount can be challenging, especially with an active, squirmy partner on bottom. A simple set of wedges at the shoulders provides one good solution - you may not be able to stop their movement completely, but you can restrict it long enough to regain control and set up your submission. When you’re solving small problems, like this, ultimately you’ll find that you have to focus on just one thing at at time. Even though simplifying your training may sometimes seem a complex undertaking, you can start by choosing one thing to focus on, taking care of that and then moving on to the next one.

Associations: strength, speed, power, attention, time…while all of these can play significant roles in your performance and growth in jiu-jitsu, one element that’s frequently overlooked is your ASSOCIATIONS. Who you spend time with doesn’t only determine your work rate on the mat or the sorts of technical challenges that drive you to improve. Your associations determine what you think about, what you aspire to and what sorts of opportunities you intersect with. Those aspirations and intersections lead to changes - in perspective as well as in technique. And those changes in turn lead us to different outcomes. So if you’d like to change your results, don’t only work on moves, techniques or your process. You can change your outcome by changing your circle. @romanbravoyoung

Inside position/outside position: the battle for inside position starts the moment you get your grips. In the case of standing vs supine guard passing - as when we use a toreando setup - finding a grip that allows you to gain inside position can be a huge advantage. Rather than simply grabbing wherever you can, learn to be specific about where you control the pants. There are a few good ways to do this, but whichever you select it should allow you to occupy the space INSIDE your partner’s shins. Jockeying for good elbow position will then allow you to direct where their feet go, denying them the strong inside posts or lassos that can make your passing so difficult. Keep in mind that there are no permanent grips, so you’ll need to make small adjustments according to your partners reactions and responses 😃

Commitment: time is an extremely valuable expenditure. Of all the things we can find and make and get, time isn’t one of them. Learning and knowledge take time, and whatever you spend can’t be replaced. That’s why you have to differentiate between being a casual learner and serious learner. It doesn’t matter if you’re a professional or a full- time grappler or an instructor. Once you understand this as a choice, you'll see opportunities to transition from being a vague generalist to being an intensive specialist all around you.
Commitment is a powerful amplifier for this process. It can take a weak signal and make it stronger. Like the best moves in jiu-jitsu, commitment is a leverage point which makes your time work harder than it otherwise might. You make an uncommon investment when you put yourself completely behind an effort or an idea and when you're all in, you get a significant return. Choose to go from casual to serious and make your time worth more.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Back with the GOAT: techniques and tactics are always important - but don’t overlook the importance of developing and cultivating the RELATIONSHIPS that feed your practice. We need support and resistance in proper measure, at the right time and place, on and off the mat. The placement in our lives of these two opposite but critical elements makes an incredible difference for our results. As a rule, we seek support when we experience instability - in the same way we post a leg for base when we resist our partner’s sweep, we also look for ways to regain our equilibrium when we’re out of balance. But support in the wrong areas can be disastrous, and we can find ourselves developing habits or traits that undermine our progress. So we need resistance - something to push back against - if we want to move beyond our present level. But then again, in the wrong places we can lose morale and the confidence to carry on: we don’t get a look at the tiny successes that power us past uncertainty. Finding - or more importantly, BUILDING - the proper ratio takes time, work and patience. And the right people. Thanks @gordonlovesjiujitsu
📸 @leviventura.media // @shoyoroll

Clamp drill: here is a great drill from @placisantos to help develop hip movement when working the clamp from the closed guard. You’ll notice that he’s actively escaping his hip each time he switches sides, and he’s making sure the inside knee really slips through to that wedge position in front of the deltoid. Drills like this are helpful because they force us to focus our efforts, something that’s essential when you’re developing a new skill. Many people don’t like constraints in training, but they help us to reduce our cognitive load, eliminate the temptation to work on low-priority skills and let us get back to work when we’re stuck. Constraints can be anything from position-specific training, regularly reviewing and drilling the same material for a set period of time, or focusing only on a small subset of techniques. When you give your practice a set of guardrails like this, they help you to avoid pitfalls AND provide the reinforcement we need to stay productive and see measurable progress in a reasonable time.

Expertise: my teacher always taught that proficiency in jiu-jitsu is a matter of technique, but working with my friend @nicholasmeregali I’m always reminded that there’s a difference between PROFICIENCY and EXPERTISE. To become proficient we usually acquire our skills by repeatedly applying a rule, in the same way a cook follows a recipe. But if you’ve ever had an extraordinary meal you know that what a good cook knows and understands isn’t confined to what’s found in a cookbook. Through practice we don’t only acquire technique - we acquire judgement. And with judgement there’s no shortcut we can take, no recipe we can follow. When you succeed in jiu-jitsu at this level you don’t just become a good rule-follower. You become a good (or even great) practitioner, someone who’s able to wield the right tools at the right time with intelligence and skill. Ultimately you get good at jiu-jitsu by doing jiu-jitsu often, so repeated practice can give you exposure to the problems you need to solve to improve and make better choices. And if you’re lucky you get to do it with others who are better than you and have a good time doing it :) 
📸 @leviventura.media // @shoyoroll

Creativity: standing, scrambles and leglocks 😜 Becoming more familiar with the skills OUTSIDE your current area of expertise takes specific practice. A big part of that is technical learning and understanding the moves that make up your area of inquiry - the gripping for your takedowns, footwork for your counters or leg positioning for your leg locks.  An equally large part is putting that work into practice with CREATIVITY in the moment. That’s the real-life activity, experimentation and interactions that bring life to what you’re learning. If you can dedicate some time to what MIGHT work, you’ll come across those elements and ingredients that you need in order to improve your efforts. Developing creativity is more than just increasing your risk-taking - it’s about making room for curiosity so you can balance the science with the art.

Long view: in the practice of jiu-jitsu we have a choice between long-term and short-term. We’d like our short-term decisions to add up to positive long-term results, even if they don’t seem to move the needle too much in the moment. This happens with grips: small grip adjustments in the moment can results in the sort of tactical advantage you need to create the angle you need to outflank your partner’s legs. Without taking those small, immediate actions it’s much harder to reach your long-term outcome. But there is a difference between WORKING short-term and THINKING short-term. If all you do is concentrate on your immediate results, you may be more willing to cut corners, ignore the downsides, bypass the rules - because it’s easy to rationalize short-term actions in the name of urgency. Taking the long view may not always yield short-term wins. But there’s plenty of room for success when you take a longer view than the others.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

In many ways half butterfly guard is the best of both worlds. Want a way to keep a lower body connection with your partner while setting up sumi gaeshi and pinch headlock attacks? Half butterfly has the answer. Want a strong elevator hook that allows you get underneath your partner and elevate them for leglock and inversions? Half butterfly has the answer for that too. A good place to begin is by making the distinction between when it’s time to focus on the upper body (head and arms) and when it’s time to focus on the lower body (legs and hips). Your first attack may fail, but in that failure it will always give you insight into your partner’s reactions and responses. If you learn their reactions, you become like a fortune-teller: you can predict what will come next. Then chaining your half butterfly attacks together will become more natural, efficient and effective. (Link to my instructional in bio!)
@judoshintaronyc // video 🎥 @gragin1 // @shoyoroll

Disorder: on the mat – as in the rest of our lives - we encounter both ordered and unpredictable elements. Most situations we find ourselves in are not completely one or the other. There are those things you can predict with relative certainty because you’ve seen them happen before...then there are things that ARE too variable to predict. That’s part of what makes a scramble in jiu-jitsu a scramble: our regular, linear approach doesn't work. All the recommendations that serve you in predictable, well-ordered circumstances suddenly seem useless. They may need additional requirements before they work, or else they may stop working entirely. In training no situation is ever purely complex and unmanageable, but whenever we try to use “normal” procedures for managing non-normal situations, we get into trouble. You can work with this part of jiu-jitsu by looking for REGULARITIES IN OTHERWISE COMPLEX SITUATIONS. Does your partner always react the same way when you pull or push them? Is there a leg or arm position you can recognize? Practicing like this means putting yourself in the midst of disorder - jiu-jitsu teaches that it’s worth our time to try to find order in such chaotic situations. Have a system you can use, know when to use it - and then know what to do when it stops working. 
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Worry: novices often ask experts what they should worry about. Should I worry about head control from inside the guard? Should I worry about the knee position relative to my ankle? Should I worry about getting swept if I stand up? Actually, WORRYING about anything doesn’t usually pay off. Of course it benefits you to pay attention to where their kneeline is, or why your posture is compromised, or if you’ve been off-balanced. LEARNING about those things (rather than WORRYING about them) will help you to make better decisions when you’re faced with them. 
Experts make this distinction all the time – they translate “worry” to “attention”. They become more and more rigorous about where attention belongs, and they get experience doing it in complex situations. When you learn to pre-empt worry with attention, you can dedicate your valuable (and limited) resources to those things that can propel you forward. 
@shoyoroll @nicholasmeregali

Patience: whether you’re a fast learner or a slow one, you’ll find there’s an almost universal experience of impatience embedded in the learning process. Guard passing, inversions, takedowns – no matter the topic, you often want to get to the end so you can see the finished result. If instead of rushing through it you can learn to become PATIENT with the process, enjoying the effort you have to exert in research and discovery, you’ll find a kind of organic growth that stays with you over the long-term. Looking back, the extra time you put in won’t seem exhausting and laborious - it’ll seem invaluable.

Vigilance: being vigilant means learning to become a keen observer, not only of what’s going on AROUND you but what’s going on INSIDE you as well. Alertness itself is a kind of agility; with it comes the sort of coordinated action that allows you to unite all your best resources, techniques and strategies. If your instinct is distress or panic you quickly lose the ability to respond well. Fears, even the most basic ones, can totally shut down our capacity for problem-solving. You may have to worry a little bit sometimes – in jiu-jitsu your defensive responses and your counter-offense require being on your toes, so it's a useful trigger to bring the right elements of the picture into focus. But vigilance means keeping all the elements in check and not letting stress of the moment overwhelm you.
@romanbravoyoung

Exposure vs. Absorption: you’re exposed to a thousand great ideas and opportunities each day. If you’re the student, your teacher and your peers hand you the building blocks for growth; if you’re the teacher, your students and peers do the same. As a practitioner, you get immediate feedback on whether something is working or not. There’s the chance to learn from your own mistakes as well as the mistakes of others. The trouble is you may not notice most of them. The difference isn’t whether you are EXPOSED to great information - its whether you can NOTICE it and ABSORB it.
Mostly we’re trained to be passive listeners, to sit still and get through it. But absorbing what’s important is an ACTIVE process. It takes consideration, experimentation, involvement, commitment. This applies to technique but to everything else as well – strategy, mindset, even training atmosphere. Absorption isn’t passive or casual, so go the extra mile and give serious attention to those techniques, tactics and concepts that can make the biggest difference for you in your practice right now.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Wedges: the leg drag is a great technique, but it’s usually hard to fight someone’s legs with your arms. It’s much less effort to trap them with a larger part of your body, like your hips, legs or chest. In that way you can hold the leg in place and restrict movement by putting something IN FRONT OF and something BEHIND the joint you want to control. This is the value of wedging whenever you’re passing the guard - to put a brake on your partner’s movement. The better your wedges, the more difficult it will be for them to move freely. You won’t be able to prevent them from moving forever of course, but you can often slow them down long enough to gain an advantage in position which you can build from. This is particularly useful with a flexible, athletic or frantic person. So whenever you can, look for ways to use MORE than just the strength of your arms to control your partners legs. Whenever you can trap a leg in the geometry of your body – shelfing it at your hip, pinning it between your chest and quad, sandwiching it between your elbow and ribs - you’ll have a way of stabilizing it through connection rather than pure strength.
@judoshintaronyc // video 🎥 @gragin1 // @shoyoroll

Learn to layer skills: whenever there’s a space between your present skills and where you want them to be, look for smaller, intermediate skills that help you bridge the gap. This is one way of tackling a major problem you’re facing. If you think of this distance as unbridgeable - a massive chasm - you’ll always feel stuck where you are. If you ignore it and go about your 
business, you’ll remain stuck. So the “big problem” you’re facing might NOT be that you’re just not trying enough, that you lack persistence or that something in the technique you’re using is wrong. It might be that you haven’t built the right context yet for the techniques you know. Build the smaller steps and the larger leap isn’t so hard.
