Unstuck: whenever you’re bogged down by a particular problem in your training, one of the best ways to get unstuck is to start down a path - even if it’s the wrong one. The corollary of this is not to wait but to do it AS SOON AS POSSIBLE. Step by step is the only meaningful way out. As you start moving you can’t help but improve, even if it’s slower than you might like. The reason we get stuck on something is often because we’re waiting for exactly the right answer to show itself. Sometimes you have to start without seeing the end - you might not end up with the perfect answer, but you’ll find yourself drifting incrementally towards the solution, even if you don’t know exactly what it is.

Throw-for-throw: there are no coins with only one side - you can’t have heads without tails. Jiu-jitsu and judo are structured the same way. There can’t be a throw without an uke; there can’t be a drill without a partner. In order to get the complete picture, we need to be prepared to play both roles. If this is your mindset in training then the flip side of “active practice” or performing the move isn’t “passive practice” and zoning out - it’s a different and complementary form of working with the technique. As uke you come to more fully understand the resistance, direction, movement and force required for a technique. If you just turn everything off when you’re not “doing the move” you’ll be wasting a significant opportunity to learn. Whether you’re throwing or being thrown, stay engaged and don’t miss the chance to see both sides of the coin. 
@eugenenyc // video 🎥 @gragin1 // @shoyoroll

Tough decisions: jiu-jitsu is full of tradeoffs. We‘re often faced with having to lose something in one area in return for gaining something in another. It’s the choice between the hanging on to the submission or guard pass that’s almost-but-not-exactly there, and moving on to the next opportunity. Changing our tactics midstream is a skill…which means you can train it. The skill starts with recognizing what’s no longer working and then letting that go. And it can be an outdated mindset just as much as it can be an outdated technique or strategy. Developing the discipline to make these adjustments can alter your direction immediately. What we learn from jiu-jitsu training is that we can't change destinations immediately. But we can change DIRECTION immediately, and direction is very important.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Daily practice: one of the first lessons my teacher ever taught me was the value of consistency and routine. There is a massive difference between the things you do every single day - and the things you do only when you’re inspired or motivated to do them. After you’ve committed to doing something daily, you find that you’re impelled to do it daily. Instead of arguing or discussing the program EVERY DAY you only make the decision ONCE. Then all that’s left each day is to decide HOW you’ll do it. @judoshintaronyc

#judo #bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #martialarts #mma

Depth: in school you might remember trying to work quickly (and at high intensity) to absorb as much as possible right before a test. It’s called cramming. Cramming is good for shallow recall that lasts about as long as the exam, but can’t produce any deep understanding of the material. The reason has nothing to do with the subject or how much time before the test. It’s because cramming doesn’t change habits - and habits are where our jiu-jitsu (and our life) is made. If you want better jiu-jitsu, the way to get it isn’t by trying to rapidly and intensively absorb some technique or skill. It’s to go to class and train, go home and shower and wash your gear, then come back and do it again. If you can do that every single day for a month, you’ll be on your way to changing your habits. Pretty soon you’ll start to see some changes while you’re there. Big goals can be very motivational and they’re good to have. Just don’t let them distract you from the thing that might really be in your way - your habits. To shift them can make a big difference in your results, one that may mean reinventing how you see yourself and what’s possible.
@peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Teaching: back again with @bjj.fanatics for the forthcoming (and final) release in the "Under Pressure" series. Our focus in this one will be on leg entanglements and how we can use LEG-TO-LEG connections when under pressure to control distance, generate kuzushi and create submission threats. One of the core concepts we covered was the notion that every technique has a CONTEXT. The context is the lens through which you view what you’re doing - it informs your decisions and guides your choices in jiu-jitsu. 
Even as a beginner, you can begin to see BEYOND individual “moves” once you start to see them according to their context. With this in mind, the techniques you learn don’t exist in isolation; they’re strands that make up a longer cable which you can use to maneuver your way through difficult terrain. My teacher @danaherjohn has always emphasized not just getting the WHAT of the technique, but also understanding WHERE and WHY you’re putting it to use. Approaching your practice like this adds a depth of understanding that helps you to work in even very unfamiliar situations. Thank you again to @michaelzenga @bernardofariabjj, @randyciak and @placisantos for their generosity and help during our work together. Look forward to sharing this with you soon 😊

Osoto: it’s said in judo that osoto is the first throw you learn and the last throw you master. In practice, I’ve found that one of the hardest parts about osoto as it’s conventionally taught is having to chop away the base leg (as a jiu-jitsu practitioner I’m always a little nervous about hacking away at someone’s stiff supporting leg 😳). Thankfully when I first learned osoto, it was using a “hook and hop“ method that’s less explosive and a bit more incremental. The variations here are all situations involving a strong leg and immobile partner where the solution is getting your hip close to (and even underneath) your partner. Big problems, big solutions 😊

Challenges: jiu-jitsu is at its best when it presents us with challenges that are just outside our reach. The partner who you can easily manage can only do so much. Having to prepare for someone whose skills exceed your own, on the other hand, requires special preparation. The best ask you to evolve, to rise to the occasion. They show you that with enough preparation, commitment and hard work, you can meet the challenges of the moment. Needing to get ready in this way is tough for a little while - but the sacrifice is worth it. In the meantime, you‘be got to do your planning with what you have NOW in anticipation of what’s to come LATER.

Scrambling: in a scramble, the main issue is knowing what to prioritize. If you can zoom in on the problem you need to solve first, you’ll have a skeleton key to unlock all other doors. 
One way is to address the most OBVIOUS issue: if someone is attacking your back, begin to separate yourself from them so you can escape. Another is to draw on your MEMORY of past experiences - if you've been in this situation before, you may recall what allowed you to come out on top last time. Finally IMAGINATION: you could put yourself in their shoes and imagine what your partner is thinking in the moment - what is their goal, where are they going? In a scramble you may not have clear control. That doesn’t mean you can’t prioritize, gain some quick insight and move from a reactive cycle into a proactive one. 
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Everything is a compromise: it’s possible to build the sort of jiu-jitsu where you’re never submitted, regardless of the power and strength of your partner. The thing is that you’ll be so defensive - avoiding all risks and playing so tight and so rigid - that you won’t develop any meaningful offense either. We compromise every time we engage with a partner, finding a balance between playing safe and risking defeat. It’s possible that things will line up and your partner will give you exactly what you want - except that in jiu-jitsu, other humans never want exactly what you want. We build that reality into our expectations about what’s possible and we compromise whenever we engage with them. Once we acknowledge that forward motion in training involves compromise, we can get to the actual question - “HOW MUCH?” Never compromising may be the safer option - the surest way never to lose is not to play - but it’s hard to get better that way. @garrytonon
@peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Playing loose: the process of developing new ideas and integrating new skills is a both technical and creative. To work, it has to be open-ended and loose enough so you can maneuver yourself into position. Eventually you may need to tighten everything up – but at the outset, you have to be flexible enough to make a few mistakes so you can see what you’re missing. Starting with tightness, pressure or competitiveness can actually be stifling, blocking the flow of ideas and associations you need in order to fully integrate something new into what you know already.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

The right way: when you practice the right way, you learn that there are clear rewards for doing something well. You discover you can bring a valuable new skill into the mix AND turn it an anchor point for a whole host of other useful activities. Think about when you first learn the knee-elbow escape from the bottom of the mount: by learning to do it well, you add massive value to nearly all the other things you try to do. It literally makes space for submissions, escapes and reversals - your half-guard and open guards improve as a result, and you get better at escaping back control and cross-side pins. Not only that, but you become more confident in unfamiliar territory and less anxious in difficult situations. High-value activities, practiced well and done with precision, bring enormous rewards. They’re ALWAYS worth the extra time it takes to get them right. 
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Handfighting, ankle picks and MORE: at first it may seem like grip fighting is a “minor” skill, secondary to the takedown itself – but it’s an absolutely critical one if you want to create the kuzushi and reactions that lead to your major attacks from the feet. Each stage of the process matters; when we look at jiu-jitsu as an aggregate of our efforts rather than results of a single moment, we can start to see how the pieces fit together. We begin with one grip and connect it to others. We start with one attack and link it to the next. Like many other things in life, each undertaking isn’t a separate undertaking - everything we do is a link in the chain of events and actions that brings us closer to our ultimate objective.
@judoshintaronyc // 📹@gragin1

Status quo: when something’s working for you, it’s natural to construct a sort of “bureaucracy” around it because you need to keep it from disappearing. But it takes some experience to discern what to keep and what to get rid of. Forcefully blasting your way out of the mounted position, aggressively kicking your way out of a heelhook, yanking your arm out of an armlock - these things will work but only up to a point. If you latch onto those as successful tactics and build your defensive game around them, though, you’ll start to see their limits soon enough. The bureaucracy you protect can be “force” or “habit” or "fear" or any other rigid, non-adaptive plan. A much more resilient approach is to fight off the instinct to support the “bureaucracy” and start to look for better solutions. Techniques, tactics and strategies - and we ourselves - have the chance to evolve when we stop focusing on short-term costs and start looking at long-term benefits.
📸@peterpabon // @shoyoroll===

Variations: in work as nuanced as judo and jiu-jitsu, it makes sense to focus on depth rather than breath. But that doesn’t mean that you shouldn’t be well acquainted with useful variations on some of your favorite moves! Whether you’re working in the standing position on the ground, have build some familiarity with common Variations on a theme. To me, tomoe nage and yoko tomoe nage never get old - low risk and high reward, they’re particularly useful both as a “bail out” technique in judo (when you’re out gripped and more conventional standing attacks don’t work) and as an excellent alternative to pulling guard to get things down to the ground in jujitsu. Not all grips, partners and situations are the same…so getting to know a few alternatives to standard entries on your “tokui waza” (favorite techniques) is worth your time!

Forging connections: one of your first objectives in jiu-jitsu is to find a way to form a good connection to your partner. From bottom position, these connections can look many ways - half-guard and half-butterfly variations are a great start. And whenever we make a transition (like from half to half-butterfly), we STILL want to maximize contact and connection with our partner. The connections you form give you better control over the distance between you - and ultimately allow you to progress to controlling the inside position. The main purpose of inside position is making or keeping space while your partner tries to close it; you can then use that space to your advantage. So whenever you’re making a change from one position to the other, keep your connection as best you can. As you improve the quality of your connection, you’ll also improve your control. (Link to my instructional in bio!)

The unturned stone: we all have a limited amount of time to train, practice and work to perfect what we’re doing, so no matter how voracious your appetite for new techniques you’ll find that you simply can’t investigate EVERYTHING. There’s no way to stay on top of every new move that shows up. If you try, you end up chasing trends on a never-ending hamster wheel. In this way you’ll definitely see a lot - but you’ll understand very little. So although it goes against conventional wisdom, in jiu-jitsu it makes sense to LEAVE SOME STONES UNTURNED. The frenzied search for more can be a distraction, a place to hide from the repetitive slogging that actually yields strong new skills. Better to pick the right stones and turn them over fully - and if they’re the wrong stones, just leave them unturned.
📸 @peterpabon

Pressure drop: I couldn’t be happier to announce the release of the final part of our “Under Pressure” series with BJJ Fanatics - this time with a focus on managing distance through LEG ENTANGLEMENTS. Of course ashi garami itself is a key player - but this instructional is really about the synergy that comes from what we might call the “CORE 4” of leg entanglements: ashi garami, x-guard, de la riva and reverse de la riva (plus their variations). In my teacher @danaherjohn’s instruction (and in my own experience), these are the most frequently seen and highest-percentage methods of controlling distance, space and pressure with strong, fast, athletic people on the mat. In keeping with the central theme of our “Under Pressure” series, this instructional was developed for those of you who know the feeling of being squashed, smashed or steamrolled by a strong, mobile, aggressive passer. If you learn to form a meaningful connection to your partner using your legs, you can truly bring to bear the "maximizing" philosophy to retain guard AND move immediately into your attacks. These “Core Four“ are the same techniques I've personally found to be successful over the years against people much tougher and stronger than me. They’ve helped me understand how to spend less time under someone else's pressure and more time CREATING pressure of my own - and I believe they can do the same thing for you! Thank you @bjjfanatics, @bernardofaria and @michaelzenga for helping to make this video happen 😀

Adjustments: one of the most tried and true axioms in jiu-jitsu is when you can’t move your partner, you have to move yourself. Since the length of your arms and legs isn’t something you have much control over, making strangle adjustments for arm triangles (like the d’arce or katagatame) with a bigger partner involves adjusting yourself to accommodate the situation. Being mentally flexible enough to make these sorts of changes allows you to adapt your technique to all sorts of body types. We often become invested in an approach because it’s worked in the past, because it’s familiar, because it’s what we’re comfortable with. But when something isn’t working – if a plan or strategy or an approach doesn’t seem to make sense – it’s important to make a change. If you have been doing things a certain way for a long time, making an adjustment to your way of thinking can be very hard…but there’s nothing that says that we have to stick with a strategy that’s isn’t right just because it’s how we’ve always done it.
video 🎥 @gragin1 // @shoyoroll

Variations vs. deviations: the nature of jiu-jitsu is such that resistance will lead you to make small adjustments in order to accomplish your goal. With experience, you can distinguish between when you need to adhere strictly to the technique or strategy and when you can make those adjustments. This flexibility has as much to do with your mindset as with your physical capabilities - when you expect someone to react “normally” - not to deviate in their response - you’re setting yourself up for failure. Of course it’s great when things work in straight lines, when one size fits all and your out-of-the-box answer solves the problem. But usually that’s not the case. If you can accept differences as VARIATIONS not DEVIATIONS - each acceptable and workable - you realize that there are many choices and many solutions. Your partner can make the choices they want and you can still stick to your plan, despite their resistance. 
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

It’s simple: at a distance, most challenges are simple - but up close in practice, when you actually have to make something work, they’re rather complicated. Your choices in jiu-jitsu are both simple AND complicated. Your goals and your strategy must be simple. Your tactics, on the other hand, need to be layered, multi-dimensional and reflect the restraint and maturity of someone who cares about actually reaching the goal. The simplicity we seek for our solutions doesn’t always lead to the patience we need to get to them. Working with nuance is the sign of a flexible, intelligent student - but it takes clarity and certainty to put subtlety and nuance into practice. 
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Half measures: half tai-otoshi is an excellent way to disrupt your partner’s balance and open other avenues of attack from the feet. And the entry is much less intimidating, especially for jiu-jitsu practitioners: rather than blocking the far leg, you only need to connect with the near one. What looks like a “failed” technique sets up reactions for successful ones - yoko tomoe, jujigatame, tai otoshi and uchimata. Wherever we have a system with resistance, action and reaction are always operating. And like many action-reaction sequences, this one is about creating OPPORTUNITY rather than a guaranteed solution to a problem. Many of your efforts won’t work at first. Your job is to make sure that when something fails, the gap that’s left is large enough for you to make something of it.
video 🎥 @gragin1

New roads: if you’ve lived in a place for any length of time, you’ll notice that eventually old buildings get torn down and new buildings go up. Roads, on the other hand, don’t change too much. Here in NYC, in the oldest parts most of the original buildings are gone but the cobblestone streets are still there. The parts of the system that create connections, transportation and communication between elements take a long time to plan and build. Then once they’re there - if they’re useful and functional - they stay. The buildings along the way will change depending on trends and who owns them. Jiu-jitsu works the same way: your techniques will change and evolve over time but the concepts underlying them won’t. So if you want to have a solid, reliable and robust practice, it helps to focus on the roads - not the buildings.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Competence - not perfection - cuts through resistance: in the early stages of training or skill acquisition, we have to get past our own resistance as well as other people’s. No one likes making errors in timing, fumbling with grips or stumbling through new technqiues (not to mention looking bad). So the first stop on the train is basic competence - the execution (often with considerable effort) of a simple, baseline goal, shows us that there’s a benefit to sticking to it through our unwillingness and mental anguish. We slice through our exhaustion, laziness, frustration and fear by building a level of competence, not through making everything flawless. HOW we become competent is really a question of exposure and work, and it's why the broad path of “mastery” makes sense. Even if mastery is an unattainable goal - it’s a process, so you can't actually arrive at it - the work that we do in the going towards it breaks down some of our fundamental resistance to the trouble areas. So showing up again and again and again and again to practice, we become more capable and find out that it’s possible to inoculate against our own resistance and fear. That initial bare proficiency - being just nimble enough - can see us through the hard times.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll
===
#bjj #jiujitsu #shoyoroll #wrestling #grappling #judo #martialarts #mma #newwavejiujitsu

Real limits (SWIPE RIGHT): jiu-jitsu itself operates on the idea that there are actual limits to the human body. There’s only so much pressure your carotid arteries can take, just like there’s only so far your elbow can extend. As a practitioner you also quickly come to understand that you have your own individual limits - like how long your arms or legs are or how tall you are 😜. Such limits are easy to identify and we rarely have a problem discovering them. These are the real limits - but there are also FALSE LIMITS. These are  the ones that other people put on us. Even when the “limiter” means well, trying to save us from frustration or wasted effort, those limits can become a habit, not something useful. If you trust someone, your teacher or your friends or your peers, to help you evolve and grow, it helps if they believe it’s possible. That while your body might be limited, you can ALWAYS update your approach, bring your best tools to a problem and do the hard work of solving it. 
📸 @peterpabon // @manto_original

Engagement vs disengagement: butterfly half guard is best when you face a partner who is ready to ENGAGE from half, not one who hopes to stall or disengage. In many ways it’s the best of all possible worlds - opportunities to access both legs and upper body AND to play them off each other. You have total inside position with your legs so they’re safe as you work (unlike the knee shield). But it has one shortcoming - it can be hard to pull someone IN. So then it’s time to make a change to adjust distance and change the range for a new set of attacks. More about HALF-BUTTERFLY from @bjj.fanatics in stories!

Tunnel vision: the flip side of focus is a sort of tunnel vision - where we latch onto a strategy or a technique and try to make it work at any cost. In the tunnel it’s easy overlook the actual circumstances - what is really there - because we have some "thing" we're trying to do. One of my teacher’s main instructions has always been about having an awareness of when it’s time to change from one system to another. If we don’t realize that the scenario has changed - that our partner has moved out of position, the distance is off, the angle is wrong - we end up working in the past, not the present. Every once in a while we have to look around, see things as they're happening and check up to make sure we are where we think we are.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Resistance: in training new problems constantly unfold before us, so we're constantly tasked with staying in front of them. We don't need to concoct extraordinarily tough situations to test this out - in most cases regular daily training is enough. To get past resistance to dealing with adverse situations, one strategy is to build “non-defensive defenses” - responses that address an issue without getting into a defensive mindset. Unfortunately, there's no set prescription - what we need changes all the time depending on circumstances. Sometimes it’s agility and movement; other times its patience and stability. Part of the work of being a practitioner is to develop a forward-thinking, proactive set of tools that we can rely on. To do this, to come up with alternative strategies, means being creative, flexible and – most importantly - resilient in bouncing back from harsh circumstances without taking them too heavily.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Consequences: jiu-jitsu is highly-consequential. Small errors can create a cascade of problems and small advances can create a cascade of opportunities. While not all decisions you make on the mat are are equally high-consequence, leaving the safety of the known for the uncertain is usually difficult. So how do you head into a new topic of study when it’s virtually guaranteed that you’re going to see mistakes and failures up ahead? One lesson my teacher taught me was to put my curiosity ahead of my “ideal performance” at the outset. Your initial efforts on something new will never meet the standards of your present skills - it’s your job as a student-practitioner to drive those efforts up until they match your present standards. When you’re tackling a new subject, regardless of difficulty, you’ll want to learn the foundational positions and movements necessary to climb from one rung to the next. The central question is, “what can I find out about this?” When your mindset can embrace a difficult area in this way, you’ll create a your own path to practice and learn something unfamiliar.
📸 @jeffreyschu // @shoyoroll

All or nothing: if you’re injured or sidelined, you can often feel left behind - you’re missing out and everyone’s passing you by because they’re out there working while you’ve had to be on hiatus. It can help to remember that over a long enough time horizon, everyone has to recharge, readjust or rest; either that or they debilitate their resources and exit for good. Another thing to remember is that coming back doesn’t have to be a reason to overcompensate - you don’t have to play catch-up. Choose a rhythm appropriate for regaining our lost ground. If you start where you are, rather than where you want to be, you’ve got a better shot to get back on track more quickly. Full conversation with @judoshintaronyc on YouTube. 
🎥 @gragin1

Observation: over the years there have been plenty of times when I’ve learned as much from watching other people’s successes and errors as I have in practicing to improve my own skills. Done well, it’s more than just casually looking around the room to watch victories and defeats. It’s like reviewing a case-study in tactics, techniques and strategies. You learn not only from your own effort - you also learn from the trials and errors of those around you. It’s a great skill to develop if you can’t participate but you don’t have to wait until then to make use of it. Full conversation with @judoshintaronyc on YouTube.

Disruptions: the unexpected elements we encounter can push us into either flexibility or inflexibility. When you get FRUSTRATED because of something unexpected, you tend to tighten up and look around for ways to seal up what’s leaking, to close the gap. When you get CURIOUS because something turned out differently than expected, you often discover that you have a new avenue to explore. In jiu-jitsu the hard part is knowing that you haven’t accounted for all the variables and that there’ll be some disruptions...but finding a way to STILL kind of look forward to it. At the end of the day if your plan can only succeed when all variables are accounted for - in other words, there’s no turbulence at all - it’s probably not a very realistic plan. The art is in knowing that you can balance excitement and nervousness during a disruption, and expand your perspective in the process.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Piece by piece: whatever you’re trying to improve, approach it “piece by piece” rather than “whole by whole”. Update your weakest areas a little at a time so you can go from strength to strength rather than having major gaps in your knowledge. That doesn’t mean ignoring something that’s broken - sometimes you do need to drop everything to fix a major problem. But in general if you can do a LITTLE each day to update the problem areas, you’ll always be doing SOMETHING about your biggest issues. The result is incremental improvement - over time you end up tackling the whole thing. Sometimes obsession is a good thing a but you can also fix your issues as you go, one at a time, little by little, without having to stop everything for a total and complete overhaul. 
📸 @peterpabon // @manto_original

Control: you can control how to practice, how much time to spend in preparation, and which areas to review. You can control who to enlist for help - teachers and peers – and how to seek out the counsel of those you trust and respect. The overall practice of jiu-jitsu itself gives a few key methods of technical control, like managing the inside position or using two of our own limbs to control one of our partner’s. But at the end of the day, the list of what you CAN’T control is always greater than what you CAN. This is why you have to give a lot of attention and time to the small set of things inside that circle. Control requires deep knowledge, both of the tools and of yourself. It takes a laser-like focus to keep attention on what’s available to you rather than worrying about what you’re missing.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Crossface juji details: your armlock shouldn’t only be a submission…it should also be a pin. When you shape your body to the structure of your partner’s you form a connection with a larger surface area and greater friction. One of your first objectives in jiu-jitsu is to find a good way to form this sort of connection to your partner. This connection gives you better control by taking away the space they need to push, frame or post. It also means you can tighten up your own wedges to restrict their movement. As you improve the quality of your connection, you improve your control.
📹 @gragin1

Situational goal adjustment: to wake up on time you can’t set the alarm clock when you’re tired – you have to do it when you’re fully awake and planning for the next day, otherwise you’ll be swayed by your exhaustion. So don’t adjust your goals for the future based on whatever random situation you happen to find yourself in at the moment. When we use a systematic approach to jiu-jitsu, the idea is to make plans early and in advance of when you’ll need them - then stick to them! Contrast this with trying to constantly adjust goals and plans depending on mood or circumstance.Obey the rules you set when you’re thinking clearly and strategically rather mood than the one you’re in right now - it’s the best way to stay on track. 
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Scientific approach: in jiu-jitsu, even with a well-laid plan your next steps aren’t always predetermined. Often you discover that what seemed certain and stable is much more fluid than it initially appeared. The scientific way of working through this uncertainty isn’t to pretend that you always have the right answer – it’s to engage with the process of getting CLOSER to the right answer. You lay out your hypothesis (or someone else’s, which is OK), then you show your work and make a prediction about what’s going to come next. If you’re wrong, you just start again from the beginning with a new argument, checking your work and making a better prediction. Being wrong and needing to correct your hypothesis happens as you make new choices and respond to your partner’s actions and reactions. You won’t find the right answers every time, but you WILL improve when you engage with the process that brings you closer to them.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Reversals: three quick ways to make use of one of the most underrated techniques in all jujitsu – the heist. Your ability to level change is a core competency in jiu-jitsu. It can take situations where you’re failing and put you back on top in relatively short order. With the grips and handles available with the gi, opportunities for heisting are accessible from everywhere. And because it’s not a particularly complex move, you can employ it from a variety of situations, and with all manner of partners. It takes awareness, acuity, and timing… all of which can be trained and practiced over time. On top of that, heisting is a developmental skill that adds depth to many of your other attacks and positions from the bottom. Heist more :)

Connection: when we defend an attack or a guard pass we want to CREATE space. When we’re attacking or passing we look to REMOVE space. Frames and posts are the tools the bottom person uses to make that space - so your work on top comes down to making your way inside, over, through and around them. Trying to find a way to make a connection to your partner - who is often looking to separate themself from you - can be a helpful heuristic anytime you’re not sure where to go. Control in jiu-jitsu happens by degrees; seeking ways to form a solid connection between yourself and your partner is a great starting point.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Exposure: instead of just making impulsive, intuitive decisions, you can rely on a system to guide you even through very complex situations. But when the system breaks down - like in a scramble or when you find yourself in uncharted territory - how you make decisions has to change. One way to train this without feeling overwhelmed is to practice seeking regularities in complex, moving, unfamiliar situations. It’s through EXPOSURE - when we put ourselves in the midst of the chaos and work to make sense of it - that we stop freaking out. Over time we learn to make ask better questions, make better choices, take better actions and ultimately get better results when you try to find order in disordered situations.
📸 @peterpabon

Choices: you may have less-than-optimal choices - but you still have choices. The beginning of a good escape can look awful and your chances appear slim (and they may actually be). Standing on the precipice you don’t want to jump – so you say you’re trapped. But you’re only trapped when you’re trapped. The submission in jiu-jitsu is so definitive because there’s no more to do. But until then, there are always choices and always chances. Next time you feel totally constrained, try to ask: am I done…or am I just afraid of the short-term consequences of making the choices I still can? The long-term results might be worth taking the risk and moving, instead of letting the short-term outcomes rule. Make the choice, own the results and start from a new place.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

We may forget that the best results come after many steps, not just three or four. Learning the mechanics of guard passing can be hard enough. Implementing those mechanics under pressure and sticking with them until it works means keeping the context you’re working in. It’s very easy to lose heart after only doing part of the work and seeing none of the results. This is especially true after you’ve tried to fix a persistent problem time and time again without seeing any discernible progress.Your ability to keep things in context is essential to tackling any serious trouble-spot you find yourself in. That’s why putting yourself back into those problem areas again and again is, paradoxically, the only way out of them. In returning you gain something you can’t find anywhere else – familiarity and context.
📸 @peterpabon // @shoyoroll

Clamp: as a general rule, we prize inside position – but there are time is when strategically giving up inside position can be a big advantage. The clamp is one of those times. Under normal circumstances we wouldn’t want to accept an underhook when we’re on the bottom, but when we have the clamp as our goal that underhook becomes very valuable. Transitioning from bottom cross side into the clamp actually REQUIRES that underhook. If you lose it, you lose the clamp – but you gain space and opportunities for new sorts of attacks. More details on clamp in “under pressure series” from @bjj.fanatics. Links in my bio :)

The right hills: I often tell my students that the craft of steady progress and success in jiu-jitsu comes from picking the right hills to climb. There are plenty of reasons why we might choose the wrong ones, where we end up aiming either too low or too high, usually out of anxiety or impatience. The easy ones - staying in a comfort zone, repeating the easy tasks over and over - don’t do much. And going after the steepest, most slippery grades where you can’t progress isn’t very effective either. The best are ones that are challenging enough that you struggle to make it over - but in the end you manage to do it. When you have a series of these hills they come to resemble a mountain, and a range of mountains is where your longterm progress happens.
📷 @peterpabon // @manto_original

I’m sure you’ve heard the saying, “you miss 100% of the shots you don’t take”. Well, my friend @romanbravoyoung has a corollary to that - “don’t take bad shots”. This speaks to the risks we take every time you try for a takedown or attack a submission. The better you become at assessing that risk and at reducing the likelihood that your “shot” will fail, the better off you’ll be. There are a few tried-and-true ways to tackle this: preparation through exposure and repetition is one; becoming familiar with critical skills like gripping and level-changing is another; learning setups, fakes and feints is still another. But these skills are all subordinate to the master skill of CHOOSING THE RIGHT SHOTS. Modifying a shot you’ve already taken because it’s not the right one isn’t nearly as useful as picking the right shot in the first place. Commit to the right thing - and if it’s not the right thing, don’t commit.
📷 @peterpabon

Backstage at Madison Square Garden with rock legend Maynard James Keenan @iamthebriefcase and my good friend, jiu-jitsu black belt Todd Fox. It’s always fascinating to see the habits and routines of people who excel in their chosen fields - Maynard had just finished Tool’s sound check when he stepped onto the mat; when we wrapped up, he only had about 45 minutes before he had to be on stage again for the show. For many people such a tight schedule would be a reason NOT to train - but finding ways to make your practice work no matter your schedule or responsibilities is part of being a serious practitioner. We had a great time, going heavy into details of knee levers and clamp attacks and all manner of “ageless jiu-jitsu” while the machinery of MSG was coming to life for the show. Throwing down some jiu-jitsu mats and rolling around in pajamas probably isn’t the weirdest thing that’s happened backstage at the Garden - but we still got some looks 👀 Definitely not my usual Friday night 😆 Thanks @tourtraining for making it happen!
